'''Norman W. Johnson''' (born November 12, 1930) is a [[mathematician]], previously at [[Wheaton College, Massachusetts|Wheaton College]], [[Norton, Massachusetts]].  He earned his [[Ph.D.]] from the [[University of Toronto]] in 1966 with a dissertation title of ''The Theory of Uniform Polytopes and Honeycombs'' under the supervision of  [[H. S. M. Coxeter]].

In his 1966 doctoral thesis Johnson discovered three uniform [[antiprism]]-like [[star polytope]]s named the [[Johnson antiprism]]s. Their bases are the three [[ditrigonal polyhedron|ditrigonal polyhedra]] – the [[small ditrigonal icosidodecahedron]], [[ditrigonal dodecadodecahedron]] and the [[great ditrigonal icosidodecahedron]].

In 1966 he enumerated 92 convex non-uniform polyhedra with regular faces.  [[Victor Zalgaller]] later proved (1969) that Johnson's list was complete, and the set is now known as the [[Johnson solid]]s.

More recently, Johnson has participated in the [[Uniform Polychora Project]], an effort to find and name higher-dimensional [[polytopes]].<ref>[http://www.mit.edu/~hlb/Associahedron/program.pdf] CONVEX AND ABSTRACT POLYTOPES Workshop (2005), N.Johnson — Uniform Polychora abstract</ref>

The literature on polytopes contains several references to a manuscript by Johnson titled ''Uniform Polytopes''. Although a few paper copies were circulated in the 1990s, the manuscript is still unpublished (as of 2015) and copies of it are hard to find.
